title: Breaking Bad El Camino: Alternative endings that never made it to screen
text:
There were a few different ways Jesse’s story could’ve ended (Picture: Netflix)

***Warning: Breaking Bad El Camino spoilers ahead***

Breaking Bad: El Camino was a perfect ending for Jesse Pinkman (Aaron Paul) for many fans, putting a full stop on the much-loved series with one final tale in the life of the Albuquerque meth salesman.

But it turns out that was easier said than done, and there were different ways the ending of Jesse’s story could’ve gone in the new 90minutes.

Show creator Vince Gilligan and actor Aaron Paul have since opened up about the ways the tearaway teen’s story could’ve changed – and if we’re honest, it’s actually pretty bleak in some cases.

Here’s all the different endings the team have revealed (including the actual final decision).

Jesse reads out the letter to Brock

Aaron Paul exclusively revealed to Metro.co.uk that a letter sent to young Brock Cantillo was meant to be revealed in the final moments of the film.

Brock was the six-year-old son of Jesse’s lover Andrea, who was shot and killed on her doorstep as collateral damage for Jesse’s meth war with white supremacists.

He told us: ‘There was a completely different ending. It ended with the voiceover of Jesse writing the letter to Brock and so, in the initial draft, the audience would’ve heard what was in the letter.’

Despite Aaron’s protests, the scene was cut, but the actor still has the letter to this day, and refuses to reveal its content.

‘I wish I could tell you, it’s such a beautiful letter, it’s so well thought out,’ he teased.

‘It’s actually the first thing that Vince wrote when he wrote the script, was that letter. The very first thing he wrote, he wrote a letter to Brock from Jesse, which is just… so beautiful.’

Jesse left his old life behind in the final moments of El Camino (Picture: Netflix)

Jesse saves a life but ends up in jail

Writer Vince Gilligan told Entertainment Weekly: “I didn’t get super far down the road, but it was probably going to be a young woman who needed some help. He was hiding out by the Canadian border and this woman was working at a motel as a housekeeper or something.

“[He] goes into the process of saving her, knowing full well that he’s going to suffer for it, he’s going to get caught for it, but he does it anyway.

‘The last scene would be maybe him in a jail cell but at peace for the first time since the movie began,” he continued.

After years of torture, with the help of a few friends, Jesse was given a second chance at life (Picture: Netflix)

Jesse rides off into the sunset

An idealistic version of a hard-hitting drama is sometimes the best one, and for El Camino, Vince decided to finally give Jesse a break from being beaten, shot at, chased and tortured.

With the help of vacuum cleaner salesman Ed, aka The Disappearer (Robert Forster), Jesse was able to set himself up with a new life in Alaska.

Packing his life up and trading in his hoodies for a white turtleneck, Jesse left nothing behind but a note for Brock, which while seen in Ed’s hands, was never fully read out.

With one last look in the rear view mirror, Jesse was seen having one last flashback to girlfriend Jane (Krysten Ritter) imagining she was with him as he headed to a new life.

In actuality, Jane died choking on her own vomit after a drug binge, with Jesse sound asleep next to her.

El Camino: A Breaking Bad Movie is available now on Netflix.
